SRATTA: Sample Re-ATTribution Attack of Secure Aggregation in Federated Learning.

Abstract

We consider a cross-silo federated learning (FL) setting where a machine learning model with a fully connected first layer is trained between different clients and a central server using FedAvg, and where the aggregation step can be performed with secure aggregation (SA). We present SRATTAÂ an attack relying only on aggregated models which, under realistic assumptions, (i) recovers data samples from the different clients, and (ii) groups data samples coming from the same client together. While sample recovery has already been explored in an FL setting, the ability to group samples per client, despite the use of SA, is novel. This poses a significant unforeseen security threat to FL and effectively breaks SA. We show that SRATTAÂ is both theoretically grounded and can be used in practice on realistic models and datasets. We also propose counter-measures, and claim that clients should play an active role to guarantee their privacy during training.

1 Introduction and Background

Federated learning (FL)Â Shokri and Shmatikov (2015); McMahan etÂ al. (2017) has been introduced as a privacy-preserving technique to train a model on multiple data sources or clients. The applications of FL now span multiple domains from medicineÂ OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. (2023) to financeÂ Long etÂ al. (2020), giving ways to unlock new sources of data while remaining privacy-preservingÂ Zheng etÂ al. (2022). As the adoption of this new technology grows, so do concerns about the limitations of FL regarding its actual privacy guaranteesÂ Kairouz etÂ al. (2021). Indeed, it has now become clear that naÃ¯ve gradient sharing is vulnerable to data-reconstructionÂ Zhu etÂ al. (2019), membershipÂ Shokri etÂ al. (2017), and property inferenceÂ Ganju etÂ al. (2018) attacks, which endangers privacy.

Various mechanisms to increase the privacy provided by FL have been explored by the literature, in particular differential privacy (DP) and secure aggregation (SA) protocols. Despite the absolute security guarantees they provideÂ Dwork etÂ al. (2014), current DP algorithms might impact the modelsâ€™ performancesÂ ElÂ Ouadrhiri and Abdelhadi (2022). On the other hand, SA is a cryptographic protocol that "allow[s] a collection of mutually distrust parties, each holding a private value, to collaboratively compute the sum of those values without revealing the values themselves"Â Bonawitz etÂ al. (2017). It can therefore be used to average model updates during FL training, to hide individual contributions from clients without impacting model performance. Such techniques are being used in productionÂ Heyndrickx etÂ al. (2022) as an effective way to protect user data. By hiding individual contributions, the effect of SA is twofold: (i) it virtually increases the number of accumulated gradients in one update, making gradient and update-based attacks more difficult and (ii) it prevents reconstructed samples to be attributed to specific clients.

Recently, the efficiency of SA to prevent reconstruction attacks has been questioned, as gradient attacksÂ Zhu etÂ al. (2019) can recover samples from large batches of raw gradientsÂ Yin etÂ al. (2021). In the FL setting, recent attacksÂ Geiping etÂ al. (2020); Xu etÂ al. (2022); Dimitrov etÂ al. (2022) have built on these works and manage to partially reconstruct data from FL updates in specific cases. Despite these recent works in gradient (or FL-update) attacks targeting the SA setting, the claim that, even though individual samples might be recovered, SA prevents linking those samples back to their respective clients has remained unchallenged so far.

In this work we demonstrate for the first time that the nature of FL updates does allow one to link samples, despite the use of SA, assuming the model has a fully connected first layer and that we are in the cross-silo FL setting (number of clients from 2 to 50). Targeting this newly found weakness, we devise an attack, named SRATTAÂ (Sample Re-ATTribution Attack against Secure Aggregation in Federated learning), to group samples belonging to individual clients together, recovering per-client contributions up to a permutation. This is done in the honest but curious setting, where the clients and server follow the protocol. This new breach of privacy could have important consequences in multiple real-world use-cases, such as healthcare applications, where the number of clients is typically limited. For instance, the prior knowledge that one specific sample belongs to one specific client, could be propagated to other recovered samples. In the worst-case scenario, this would lead to a one to one assignment of all samples of an individual client exposing the entirety of its dataset. This grouping threat on top of sample recovery should be addressed, as it might create other important privacy-leakages. Indeed, the knowledge that specific data are being collected by a specific client could compromise its area of research or target market. We also believe that this threat advocates for a paradigm shift in the design of privacy preserving bricks in (cross-silo) FL: clients must take a more active part in defending themselves, rather than only relying on a secure central server.

Contributions. After presenting the attack environment and assumptions we make on the model and data inÂ SectionÂ 2, we describe a theoretically justified attack which allows to recover and group samples from the aggregated updates. More specifically, we make the following contributions.

â€¢Â Â  A new analytical data-reconstruction attack on FL updates, which can target any type of loss function, using a data prior that can easily be constructed for many data modalities (SectionÂ 3.2).

â€¢Â Â  A method to group recovered samples belonging to the same client together in spite of the use of SA, unveiling a new target for attacks on cross-silo FL trainings with SA (SectionÂ 3.2).

â€¢Â Â  Evidence that SRATTAÂ poses a real threat on several benchmark datasets and machine learning tasks (SectionÂ 4).

â€¢Â Â  Defensive schemes against SRATTA, highlighting the role clients can play to guarantee their own privacy (SectionÂ 5).

We also provide a Python implementation of SRATTA, and of the proposed defensive schemes.

2 Attack environment and assumptions

This section presents the setting and main assumptions, and discusses them in light of the current literature. SectionÂ 2.1 formally introduces (i) the algorithm that SRATTAÂ targets and (ii) the quantities and information the attacker needs to access in order to perform the attack. SectionÂ 2.2 states, motivates and discusses the additional assumptions that we make, in particular concerning the machine learning (ML) models which SRATTAÂ targets. Finally, inÂ SectionÂ 2.3, we further discuss the works related to this threat model and our assumptions, both in and out the FL framework.

Assumption 2.1 (cross-silo federated averaging).

The loss inÂ EquationÂ 1 is optimized using the original FedAvg algorithmÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2017) with local minibatch SGDÂ Bottou (2012), with all clients participating at each round, and using SA at the averaging step. This algorithm is described inÂ AlgorithmsÂ 1 andÂ 2.

Regarding the aggregation done with SA, in some cases, the server has access to the aggregated parameters of the model Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} while in other implementations of SAÂ Cramer etÂ al. (2022), we do not make any assumption on the actual implementation used to perform SA as long as it works as intended. The shorthand SA thus designates an ideal invocation of such a protocol.

Finally, note thatÂ 2.1 can be relaxed without impacting the performances of SRATTAÂ (seeÂ AppendixÂ C).

Threat model

Assumption 2.2 (Threat model).

We assume a honest but curious threat model where each participant follows the protocol but tries to infer as much information as possible on the data of other participants from the quantities they receive. We further assume that no client collusion is possible (two clients cannot agree to perform an attack together), therefore placing ourselves in a particularly unfavorable setting for the attacker. The attacker described in this work is anyone who knows the target ML task, which only entails knowing the data type of each feature and whether additional preprocessing is used. In addition, the attacker has access to the aggregated model after SA at each round: Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} for tâˆˆ0,â€¦,tmaxğ‘¡0â€¦subscriptğ‘¡maxt\in 0,\dots,t_{\mathrm{max}}. If multiple trainings are performed (when testing different seeds or learning rates), the attacker has access to all the aggregated iterates from all training phases.

The attacker does not need to have access to the client-specific models. The attacker can be either the server if the cryptographic protocols used do not prevent it, or any of the clients.

2.3 is a strong assumption. It is satisfied by multi-layer perceptron (MLP) architectures, which have been scaled with success to a variety of problems such as for tabular dataÂ Kadra etÂ al. Finally, we make the following assumption.

Assumption 2.4.

Samples of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are unique.

In the cross-silo FL applications we consider (notably associated with FL for healthcare), we believe this assumption to be satisfied in a vast majority of cases. Note however that in cross-device FL settings, for example in NLP applications, the repeated presence of certain relatively short sentences could preventÂ 2.4 from holding.

In order to decide whether an element xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a true data sample from one of the clients, we use a data prior. (2022), and identify data samples as duplicates. It will therefore have to be small enough to filter out all false candidates. Our experiments will confirm that this requirement is satisfied empirically. Indeed, while the existence of a such a data prior may seem a strong hypothesis, it can be easily built using knowledge of general data properties, which are available to the attacker in our threat modelÂ 2.2. 2.3 Related work

Our work uses recent results on analytical data reconstruction attacks, in order to take advantage of FL updates to disaggregate SA.

Data reconstruction attacks

Optimization-based attacks on raw gradients. Zhu etÂ al. (2019) show that one can recover samples from a training dataset using the gradients generated during training in the case of classification tasks with cross-entropy loss and small batches. Their approach consists in generating "dummy" samples as close as possible to the real samples by matching the gradients obtained when training using the "dummy" samples with the ones observed during the real training. While this work is not specific to FL, such attacks are particularly important in FL as the gradients -or the model updates- are shared and sent over the network.

Multiple works improve the accuracy of such methods using different image priorsÂ Zhao etÂ al. (2020); Geiping etÂ al. (2020); Yin etÂ al. (2021) and scaling the attack to handle medium to large batches of gradientsÂ Yin etÂ al. (2021). Although the grouping of samples in SRATTAÂ is optimization-based like the attacks above, our data recovery step is purely analytical. Moreover, while previous attacks are limited to the use of cross-entropy loss over images, SRATTAÂ can target different dataset types and any differentiable loss.

Analytical attacks on raw gradients. Aono etÂ al. (2017); Geiping etÂ al. (2020); Pan etÂ al. (2022) point out that, in the case of a fully-connected layer, if only one sample activates a hidden neuron, the gradients of the weights corresponding to that hidden layer are proportional to the input of the layer, and the proportionality coefficients correspond to the gradient of the bias irrespective of the loss used (cfÂ SectionÂ 3.2). Zhu and Blaschko introduce an analytical reconstruction attack which recursively reconstructs activation maps layer per layer. We make use of such results in SRATTA. However (i) we scale such attacks from gradients to multiple FL updates, (ii) our method introduce the novel use of a data prior to allow an analytical reconstruction, and (iii) the core of SRATTAÂ is grouping samples from the same clients together, which is a new idea.

Attacks on FL updates. Geiping etÂ al. (2020) andÂ Xu etÂ al. (2022) show qualitatively that, if very small learning rates are used (or single-batch approximation), original optimization based attacks still work to some extent. A related approach introduced byÂ Dimitrov etÂ al. (2022) leverages higher-order automatic differentiation to fully simulate multiple gradient updates by optimizing over multiple dummy batches simultaneously. While the two previous attack rely on optimizing a gradient matching problem, a third line of work introduced byÂ Kariyappa etÂ al. (2022) optimizes an independent component analysis problem to recover individual gradient, before applying gradient inversion attacks to recover samples.

All attacks presented in this paragraph are optimization-based gradient attacks and thus suffer from the same drawbacks: they can only target image classification tasks (when using gradient matching) and more importantly do not target samples grouping at all. In addition, while all data reconstruction attacks including ours are sensitive to the number of updates, the learning-rate and the batch-size, we show in AppendixÂ E.4 that SRATTAÂ can accomodate multiple updates (up to 202020 updates) and large batch-sizes (up to 323232) while still maintaining reasonable accuracy (>10absent10>10%), which is rare in this literature.

Leveraging multiple rounds and tranings. BothÂ Xu etÂ al. (2022) andÂ Dimitrov etÂ al. (2022) exploit the redundancy of samples between each round to increase the effectiveness of the attack. SRATTAÂ also exploits this redundancy, in a novel way, when performing the grouping step (cfÂ SectionÂ 3.2).

From MLPs to convolutional neural networks (CNN). Many of the works cited in this section, such as those byÂ Pan etÂ al. (2022); Zhu and Blaschko ; Boenisch etÂ al. (2021); Kariyappa etÂ al. (2022), extend their gradient-based recovery strategy from MLPs, which satisfyÂ 2.3, to CNNs which do not satisfy this assumption anymore, by inverting the convolutional part of the network. While we believe the techniques used in these works could also be applied in our setting, our current work relies heavily onÂ 2.3, and is therefore not directly applicable to break SA for CNNs.

Disaggregating Secure Aggregation. Different lines of research tackle the problem of retrieving client-specific information from aggregated updates. However, they differ from our work: they either assume a malicious threat model, or do not group recovered samples together. Pasquini etÂ al. (2022) consider a threat model where the central server controls the updates sent to each client, exposing the data despite the use of SA, which is not the case in standard cross-silo FL training. In this attack, the malicious aggregator sends different models to each client. All but one clients receive a model that produces null gradients while one of the servers, the target, receives an unaltered model. Therefore, after SA, the aggregator can obtain the gradient from a single client. Within our threat model defined inÂ SectionÂ 2, such an attack is not possible as we assume that the central server is honest-but-curious and that the protocol prevents the aggregator from controlling the models sent to each client. Similarly,Â Zhao etÂ al. (2023); Fowl etÂ al. (2022) retrieve client data, but assuming a malicious threat model, in which the aggregator can choose the model it sends to each client. Lam etÂ al. (2021) assume that the model updates sent by each client are constant, or almost constant across the rounds, and that the participation differs between each round. They recover therefore both the participation matrix and the model updates of each client. Within our threat model and framework, defined inÂ SectionÂ 2, such an approach does not hold as: (i) the matrix participation is constant, (ii) only a small fraction of the local dataset might be used at each step, therefore there is no reason for the model updates to be constant across the rounds for a given client. Finally,Â PejÃ³ etÂ al. (2022) considers a framework similar to ours, but recover only a high level description of the data quality of each client, and not the content of their dataset.

In view of these different works, we believe there has been no other related attempts to perform sample re-attribution despite the use of SA under similar assumptions.

3 Presentation of SRATTA

In this section, we present SRATTA, our method to recover and group client samples together. The full SRATTAÂ algorithm can be found inÂ AlgorithmÂ 3.

3.1 Preliminary: activation sets

In this part, we introduce the central tool of our attack: activation sets. Intuitively, activation sets consist in samples which contribute linearly to a given weight update. We target these activation sets and partially recover them in our attack. The rest of the subsection provides formal definitions of batch and round-level activation sets, and states the associated linear decompositions.

This result, proved inÂ AppendixÂ A, is an extension of Proposition D.1 byÂ Geiping etÂ al. (2020).

Round-level activation sets Since the attacker only has access to round-level updates Î”â€‹WÂ¯thâ€‹=defâ€‹WÂ¯thâˆ’WÂ¯tâˆ’1hÎ”subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡defsubscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡1\Delta\overline{W}^{h}_{t}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\overline{W}^{h}_{t}-\overline{W}^{h}_{t-1} and not to individual batch gradients, we define the round-level activation set of neuron hâ„h during round tğ‘¡t as the union of all batch-level activation sets encountered by all clients during local training.

This proposition results from the nature of the FedAvg updates and is proved in AppendixÂ A.2. It is the cornerstone of the first two steps of SRATTA.

3.2 Main steps of SRATTA

SRATTAÂ consists of three main steps: (i) recovering samples using the data prior, (ii) recovering small activation sets, and (iii) grouping samples coming from the same client together. We emphasize that (iii) is completely novel, and highlights an important finding of the present paper: using SA does not prevent attackers from recovering groups of samples belonging to the same client.

Step 1. Sample recovery

The first step of SRATTAÂ consists in recovering individual data samples. It is based on the observation that certain samples can be recovered as a ratio of round-level updates, which is a direct consequence ofÂ PropositionÂ 3.2.

Proposition 3.3.

For any neuron hâ„h and round tğ‘¡t, if the round-level activation set ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} contains a single sample xğ‘¥x, then x=Î”â€‹Wth/Î”â€‹bthğ‘¥Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡x=\Delta W^{h}_{t}/\Delta b^{h}_{t}. We say that such a sample xğ‘¥x is an "isolated sample".

To recover all isolated samples, we start by constructing the family of ratios (rthâ€‹=defâ€‹Î”â€‹Wth/Î”â€‹bth)t,hsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ„ğ‘¡defÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„(r^{h}_{t}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\Delta W^{h}_{t}/\Delta b^{h}_{t})_{t,h} from the round-level updates, which are accessible to the attacker underÂ 2.2 (skipping (t,h)ğ‘¡â„(t,h) for which Î”â€‹bth=0Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡0\Delta b^{h}_{t}=0). We then filter out elements by only keeping those which belong to the data prior ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}, defined inÂ SectionÂ 2.2. In SRATTA, the set of recovered data samples â„›â„›\mathcal{R} is therefore defined as

â„›â€‹=defâ€‹{rthâˆˆğ’«:Î”â€‹bthâ‰ 0}.â„›defconditional-setsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ„ğ‘¡ğ’«Î”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡0\mathcal{R}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\left\{r^{h}_{t}\in\mathcal{P}\leavevmode\nobreak\ :\leavevmode\nobreak\ \Delta b^{h}_{t}\neq 0\right\}. (7)

While we are sure that â„›â„›\mathcal{R} contains all isolated samples byÂ PropositionÂ 3.3, â„›â„›\mathcal{R} may still contain "false" data samples. However, this has never happened in our experiments, and we recover a reasonable proportion of the client datasets (seeÂ SectionÂ 4). We explain this by the combination of two factors. First, our data priors are discrete, hence "small" in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. Second, if ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} is of size greater than two, the corresponding ratio rthsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ„ğ‘¡r^{h}_{t} is a sum of multiple data samples, weighted by coefficients whose structure has no link with the data prior (seeÂ PropositionÂ 3.2).

Remark 3.4 (Analytical recovery of the samples).

A recovered sample as defined inÂ EquationÂ 7 is analytically recovered: samples are reconstructed up to machine precision. In our experiments, it will therefore be irrelevant to measure the PSNR, the LPIPS or any similarity metric between the reconstruction and the original sample.

Step 2. Reconstructing small activation sets

The second step of SRATTAÂ consists in reconstructing certain round-level activation sets; this will be needed to group samples together in step 3.

To reconstruct an activation set ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}, we reverse engineerÂ PropositionÂ 3.2, and look for a linear decomposition of the round-level updates Î”â€‹WÂ¯thÎ”subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡\Delta\overline{W}^{h}_{t} in the form ofÂ EquationÂ 6, where the samples are taken in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}. More formally, for all (t,h)ğ‘¡â„(t,h), we look for Nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘â„•N\in\mathbb{N},Â (Î»r)1â‰¤râ‰¤Nâˆˆâ„dâˆ–{0}subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘0(\lambda_{r})_{1\leq r\leq N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\setminus{\{0\}} and (xr)1â‰¤râ‰¤Nâˆˆâ„›Nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptâ„›ğ‘(x_{r})_{1\leq r\leq N}\in\mathcal{R}^{N} such that

Î”â€‹WthÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡\displaystyle\Delta W^{h}_{t} =âˆ‘r=1NÎ»râ€‹xrabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}x_{r} (8a)
Î”â€‹bthÎ”subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡\displaystyle\Delta b^{h}_{t} =âˆ‘r=1NÎ»r.absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}. (8b)

In general, there is no unique solution to this problem: (i) it could have no solution if the round-level activation set ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} is not included in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}, or (ii) it could have multiple solutions if the elements of either ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} or â„›â„›\mathcal{R} are not linearly independent. The first issue is unavoidable as it depends on the quality of the recovery step, but would simply result in not recovering the specific ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}. The second issue is more problematic as it could lead to "wrong" recovered activation sets. In order to reduce the risk of linear dependencies, SRATTAÂ only attempts to recover activation sets of size smaller than a fixed threshold Nmaxâ‰ªdmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘maxğ‘‘N_{\textrm{max}}\ll d. In our applications, we set Nmax=20subscriptğ‘max20N_{\textrm{max}}=20, the smallest dataset dimension being d=180ğ‘‘180d=180.

Together with the constraint that Nâ‰¤Nmaxğ‘subscriptğ‘maxN\leq N_{\textrm{max}}, EquationÂ 8 becomes a sparse reconstruction problem (Â Zhang etÂ al. (2015), seeÂ AppendixÂ B for further details). Many algorithms exist to tackle this problem, such as orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) byÂ Mallat and Zhang (1993), or the LASSOÂ Kim etÂ al. (2007). While the assumptions to guarantee the convergence of these algorithms to a solution cannot be checked by the attacker, we found that using OMP works well in practice. At the end of this step, SRATTAÂ recovers a set ğ’œ~thsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t} of samples in â„›â„›\mathcal{R}, for all pairs (t,h)âˆˆLrecğ‘¡â„subscriptğ¿rec(t,h)\in L_{\textrm{rec}} whose associated problemÂ 8 is solved by the OMP. While the recovered ğ’œ~thsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t} are not formally guaranteed to be equal to ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}, we will assume they are to keep notations simple. This step is the most computationally expensive of SRATTA.

Step 3a). Theoretical foundation of sample grouping

The third step of SRATTAÂ consists in grouping samples which belong to the same client dataset together, and is the key contribution of the paper.

We start by providing the intuition and theoretical results which allow for this grouping of samples, before effectively using them in step 3b). For any t,hğ‘¡â„t,h, we introduce the set

ğ’œ~t,0hâ€‹=defâ€‹{xâˆˆğ’œth:Wtâˆ’1hâ€‹x+btâˆ’1h>0},subscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0defconditional-setğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡1ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â„ğ‘¡10\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\{x\in\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}\leavevmode\nobreak\ :\leavevmode\nobreak\ W^{h}_{t-1}x+b^{h}_{t-1}>0\}, (9)

which is computable by SRATTAÂ if (t,h)âˆˆLrecğ‘¡â„subscriptğ¿rec(t,h)\in L_{\textrm{rec}}. Intuitively, the set ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} contains all samples which activate neuron hâ„h at the beginning of round tğ‘¡t. These samples are the only ones which make the extended weights of the neuron hâ„h move away from their initial value. Thus, if a given client kğ‘˜k has a sample which activates neuron hâ„h during round tğ‘¡t, its first sample to activate neuron hâ„h necessarily belongs to ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0}. This reasoning yields the following central result (seeÂ SectionÂ A.3 for a proof).

Theorem 3.5.

UnderÂ 2.4, if a sample from client kğ‘˜k is in ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}, then at least one sample from client kğ‘˜k is in ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0}.

TheoremÂ 3.5 can be exploited by attackers to group samples together; while SRATTAÂ exploits it by usingÂ CorollaryÂ 3.6, there could be more elaborate ways of using this result.

Corollary 3.6.

UnderÂ 2.4:

(i)Â Â  if there is only one sample in ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0}, all samples in ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} belong to the same client.

(ii)Â Â  if all the samples in ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} belong to the same client, all samples in ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} belong to that same client.

Step 3b). Effectively matching samples in SRATTA

In this last step, SRATTAÂ leveragesÂ CorollaryÂ 3.6 to iteratively build a graph on the recovered samples â„›â„›\mathcal{R}, where edges are drawn between samples if they belong to the same client. As a result, all samples in a connected component of the graph come from the same client. Recall that at the end of step 2, we assume that SRATTAÂ has reconstructed ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} and hence ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} for all (t,h)âˆˆLrecğ‘¡â„subscriptğ¿rec(t,h)\in L_{\textrm{rec}}. Initially, there are no edges in the graph.

SRATTAÂ starts by using (i) of corollaryÂ 3.6: for all (t,h)âˆˆLrecğ‘¡â„subscriptğ¿rec(t,h)\in L_{\textrm{rec}} such that ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} is of size 111, an edge is drawn between all samples in ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}, as they belong to the same client.

SRATTAÂ then iteratively adds edges by using (ii) of corollaryÂ 3.6. For all (t,h)âˆˆLrecğ‘¡â„subscriptğ¿rec(t,h)\in L_{\textrm{rec}}, we check if ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} is included in a connected component of the graph. If this is the case, all samples in ğ’œ~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} belong to the same client: an edge is drawn between all samples in ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}.

This procedure is stopped when no new edge is added. SRATTAÂ finally returns the connected components of the graph, which is a partition (P1,â€¦,Pp)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘(P_{1},...,P_{p}) of the recovered samples: P1âˆªâ€¦âˆªPp=â„›subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘â„›P_{1}\cup...\cup P_{p}=\mathcal{R}.

4 Applying SRATTA

In this section, we evaluate the performance of SRATTAÂ on different datasets. InÂ SectionÂ 4.1, we show that SRATTAÂ allows (i) to recover an important proportion of the original data samples (step 1 of our method) and (ii) to correctly group those samples together. InÂ SectionÂ 4.2, we compare the grouping step of SRATTAÂ to a simple baseline. This comparison allows us to focus on an interesting feature of SRATTA: the fact that the grouping of samples does not depend on any heterogeneity in the sample distribution across clients: SRATTAÂ works equally well in i.i.d or non i.i.d. settings. The code for SRATTAÂ is available at https://github.com/owkin/SRATTA.

Dataset used We perform SRATTAÂ on four different datasets. Two of them are image datasets: CIFAR10Â Krizhevsky etÂ al. (2009) and FashionMNISTÂ Xiao etÂ al. (2017). One is a binary dataset, the Primate Splice-Junction Gene Sequences (hereafter DNA dataset) dataset available in the OpenML suiteÂ Vanschoren etÂ al. (2014). The final dataset is a multi-modal and multi-centric version of the TCGA-BRCAÂ Tomczak etÂ al. (2015); OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. (2022) dataset, containing binary, discrete and continuous entries. Further details on the dataset used are listed inÂ SectionÂ E.2. For FashionMNIST and CIFAR10 the possible pixel values of data samples are in ğ’«={k/255,k=0,â€¦,255}d\mathcal{P}=\{k/255,k=0,\dots,255\}^{d}, which we use as a data prior for these datasets. The DNA data are binary, therefore for this dataset ğ’«={0,1}dğ’«superscript01ğ‘‘\mathcal{P}=\{0,1\}^{d}. Finally for TCGA-BRCA, we use a data prior on a subset of the features which are binary: ğ’«={0,1}FÃ—â„dâˆ’Fğ’«superscript01ğ¹superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¹\mathcal{P}=\{0,1\}^{F}\times\mathbb{R}^{d-F}.

Metrics As noted in RemarkÂ 3.4, as the sample recovery process is exact up to machine precision, it is irrelevant to compare the recovered data samples with their original counterpart. Recall the definition of the groups Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} inferred by the attacker in Step 3 (bis). We will use the following metrics.

Ïrecoveredâ€‹=defâ€‹#â€‹â„›/#â€‹ğ’ŸsubscriptğœŒrecovereddef#â„›#ğ’Ÿ\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\#\mathcal{R}/\#\mathcal{D} is the ratio of recovered samples and measures the quality of the recovery process.

Ïmatchedâ€‹=defâ€‹â„›matched/#â€‹ğ’ŸsubscriptğœŒmatcheddefsubscriptâ„›matched#ğ’Ÿ\rho_{\mathrm{matched}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{matched}}/\#\mathcal{D}, where â„›matchedsubscriptâ„›matched\mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{matched}} is the number of samples which have been recovered and grouped with at least another sample.

ÏcomponentsubscriptğœŒcomponent\rho_{\mathrm{component}} is the ratio between the average size of the Kğ¾K largest components in the partition (P1,â€¦,Pp)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘(P_{1},...,P_{p}) and the average size of a clientâ€™s dataset.

The metrics above measure the quality of the recovery step but do not give indications on the quality of the grouping of the recovered samples. This is why we also use the Vğ‘‰V-measure of the partition (P1,â€¦,Pp)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘(P_{1},...,P_{p}) of â„›â„›\mathcal{R} w.r.t. the true partition of â„›â„›\mathcal{R} between the Kğ¾K clientsÂ Rosenberg and Hirschberg (2007): Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}}. Informally, the Vğ‘‰V-measure, Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}}, is a mix of two quantities, homogeneity: if grouped samples are from the same client, and completeness: if samples from the same client are in a single cluster.

Remark 4.1.

Note that more standard metrics such as recall or precision are insufficient to provide a satisfying ranking of different groupings as they cannot measure completeness of the partitions and would thus give a similar score to groupings of drastically different qualities.

Finally we introduce Vnormalizedâ€‹=defâ€‹ÏrecoveredÃ—Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰normalizeddefsubscriptğœŒrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{normalized}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}\times V_{\mathrm{recovered}} the Vğ‘‰Vmeasure normalized by the recovery ration in order to measure the quality of the attack as a whole (recovery and grouping). All metrics have values in [0,1]01[0,1]. This way, reported numbers are not inflated in the case where one step of the attack is failing indeed Vnormalizedsubscriptğ‘‰normalizedV_{\mathrm{normalized}} is equal to one if and only if the attack works perfectly: Ïrecovered=1subscriptğœŒrecovered1\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}=1, Ïmatched=1subscriptğœŒmatched1\rho_{\mathrm{matched}}=1, Ïcomponent=1subscriptğœŒcomponent1\rho_{\mathrm{component}}=1 and Vnormalized=1subscriptğ‘‰normalized1V_{\mathrm{normalized}}=1.

For additional details on these metrics, we refer to Â SectionÂ E.1

Running the attack We assume that the attacker is in a typical data science workflow where (i) multiple learning rates are tested, in order to select the best one, and (ii) different trainings will be run for each learning rate, in order to have a measure of the uncertainty. Thus, it is plausible that the attacker has access to training sequences for different seeds and different learning rates.

4.1 Evaluating the attack on four datasets

For each dataset, we choose realistic hyper-parameters (HP) (learning rate, number of hidden neurons), and we perform FL trainings, with 555 clients each containing #â€‹ğ’Ÿk=100#subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜100\#\mathcal{D}_{k}=100 data samples and with nupdates=5subscriptğ‘›updates5n_{\mathrm{updates}}=5, tmax=20subscriptğ‘¡max20t_{\mathrm{max}}=20, as described in SectionÂ 2.1 andÂ AlgorithmÂ 1. We then perform SRATTAÂ using only the model parameters at each round Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} and report the metrics ÏrecoveredsubscriptğœŒrecovered\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}, ÏmatchedsubscriptğœŒmatched\rho_{\mathrm{matched}}, ÏcomponentsubscriptğœŒcomponent\rho_{\mathrm{component}} and Vnormalizedsubscriptğ‘‰normalizedV_{\mathrm{normalized}} inÂ FigureÂ 1.

Impact of the hyper-parameters InÂ AppendixÂ G, we explore in detail the impact of the different HP on the performance of SRATTAÂ on FashionMNIST. It confirms the intuition that as the number of hidden neurons, trainings or tmaxsubscriptğ‘¡maxt_{\mathrm{max}} grows, so does the performance. It also demonstrates that increasing the batch size (1-32) or the number of updates (1-20) significantly degrades the quality of SRATTA. However, simply increasing these parameters would not constitute a proper defense, as the proportion of recovered samples is still significant (> 0.1). Finally, we show that there is an optimal set of learning rates for which the grouping part of the attack works particularly well. This set of learning rates does not necessarily contain the optimal learning rate in terms of performance, but is close enough so that it will be tested during an HP search.

4.2 Dependence on inter-client datasetsâ€™ homogeneity

In this section, we explore the fact that a priori, our grouping method is not sensitive to inter-client datasetsâ€™ homogeneity, as it relies on a combinatorial argument. Indeed its is harder to group samples when clientsâ€™ datasets are similar (homogeneous). In order to test this hypothesis we use Dirichlet samplingÂ Hsu etÂ al. (2019) on samplesâ€™ labels to build our clients with varying heterogeneity by varying the Î±ğ›¼\alpha parameter of the Dirichlet distribution (cf SectionÂ E.3). We compare SRATTAÂ with a naÃ¯ve attack which consists in performing a Kğ¾K-means algorithm, Kğ¾K being the number of clients, on the recovered data samples â„›â„›\mathcal{R} (from Step 1).

We compare both methods using the normalized Vğ‘‰V measure as defined above, which is particularly interesting as it takes into account both the homogeneity, which favours SRATTA, as well as completeness, which favour Kğ¾K-means. We report the results in Fig.2. In this figure, each point of the curve corresponds to a different dataset whose labels are more homogeneously distributed amongst clients as Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases. Î±ğ›¼\alpha is not a hyper-parameter chosen by the attacker or by the clients, but a parametrization of intrinsic data heterogeneity.

The Kğ¾K-means attack works well in the heterogeneous case, and not at all in the homogeneous case, while SRATTAÂ works reasonably well in all cases.

5 Fighting secure disaggregation

To defend against this new type of attack, we believe that clients should take matters into their own hands, actively controlling the updates shared to the server.

We propose the following defense mechanism. At each round tğ‘¡t, each client kğ‘˜k dynamically checks its own activation set ğ’œt,khsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t,k} of each neuron hâ„h (for a formal definition, see EquationÂ 26 in SectionÂ F.1). If this activation set is too large to be attacked (larger than a threshold qğ‘q), the corresponding update is shared. Otherwise, the neuron hâ„h is frozen:

If#â€‹ğ’œt,khâ‰¤q,WÂ¯t,k,nupdateshâ€‹Â is reset toÂ â€‹WÂ¯tâˆ’1h.formulae-sequenceIf#subscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›updatesÂ is reset toÂ superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šğ‘¡1â„\text{If}\quad\#\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t,k}\leq q,\quad\overline{W}^{h}_{t,k,n_{\mathrm{updates}}}\text{ is reset to }\overline{W}_{t-1}^{h}. (10)

This removes easy-to-recover activation sets with less than qğ‘q samples and nullifies the effect of SRATTA. This censoring might reduce the final performance of the model. However inÂ tableÂ 1, we show that we are able to effectively defend ourselves against SRATTAÂ while preserving the accuracy of the model. InÂ SectionÂ F.1,Â FiguresÂ 6 andÂ 7 we provide more evidence that this defense does not affect model accuracy independently of the learning rate. This result is coherent with related works on gradient pruningÂ Sattler etÂ al. (2019) or dropoutÂ Srivastava etÂ al. (2014) where models are efficiently trained with a higher proportion of frozen neurons than ours.

We observe situations where neurons were activated by several samples but only one of them with significant amplitude, allowing reconstruction. Moving from q=1ğ‘1q=1 to q=4ğ‘4q=4 improves the resilience of the defense to this case.

Finally, note that the grouping part of SRATTAÂ is relevant only if nupdates>1subscriptğ‘›updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}>1. Enforcing nupdates=1subscriptğ‘›updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}=1 effectively breaks sample matching, but it is out of the scope of this paper, for reasons detailed inÂ SectionÂ F.4.

5.1 Strengths and limitations of the defense

As in most adversarial settings, the defense mechanism we present in this section is not proved to be absolute. Apart from the empirical evidence presented in LABEL:fig:defense_acc_and_prun_all_datasets, two remarks strengthen our belief that knowing the defense mechanism does not result in a straightforward workaround for the attacker.

  • â€¢

    If the attacker knows that certain neurons have been censored, retrieving them is not obvious, as this censoring is done at client level, and is not directly reflected in the aggregation.

  • â€¢

    Even assuming that the attacker is able to trace which neuron has been censored by which client, they can only infer that the data point which trigerred the defense lies in a certain half space (and this is assuming the knowledge of the weights defining the half space, which is not obvious considering they are modified by local updates).

However, this does not provide a formal proof of the inviolability of the defense. Another point of concern could be that the defense could impact model accuracy, in the case where underrepresented samples are censored too often, and which is not reflected in the datasets we studied. To mitigate this concern, we note that the defense only censors the update for specific neurons for specific clients. Thus a neuron censored by Client A can be updated by Client B in this very round, and thus not be censored at another round for the same sample. Moreover, for a sample to have virtually no impact on any neuron during the training, all neurons activated by the underrepresented sample need to be censored.

6 Discussion

We believe SRATTAÂ to be an important proof of concept opening new interesting research avenues in both the design of attacks, and of privacy layers in cross-silo FL settings. In particular, it stresses the fact that clients have to play a bigger role in actively defending themselves, and that relying on secure centralized computations alone is not enough. In our work, the restriction to models with a fully connected first layer, such as MLPs, limits the impact of SRATTA.

Extension to CNNs. Assessing if this attack can be extended to a broader class of models, such as CNNs, will be important to make sure that clients implement the appropriate defense mechanisms. InÂ Pan etÂ al. (2022); Zhu and Blaschko ; Boenisch etÂ al. (2021); Kariyappa etÂ al. (2022), the attack on MLPs is extended to CNNs by attacking the first fully connected layer. The key component needed for SRATTA to work on this setting, is a prior on the deep features allowing to filter out reconstruction candidates relying solely on their feature representations as is done now in SRATTA using raw data. Previous work Pan etÂ al. (2022); Zhu and Blaschko ; Dong etÂ al. (2021) have shown that inverting the convolutional part of the network is possible, which could allow us to use priors on raw data space, and select reconstructed deep features based on their inversion to the raw data space. This is but one way to approach the problem, and we are convinced subsequent works will be able to bridge this gap.

B.2 Restriction to small activation sets

SolvingÂ EquationÂ 20 and using a resulting Î»ğœ†\lambda to build the recovered activation set ğ’œ~thâ€‹(Î»)subscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡ğœ†\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda) is not satisfactory. Indeed, as soon as Nâ„›>d+1subscriptğ‘â„›ğ‘‘1N_{\mathcal{R}}>d+1 there are infinitely many solutions toÂ EquationÂ 20, corresponding to potentially infinitely many recovered activation set ğ’œ~thâ€‹(Î»)subscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡ğœ†\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda). In that case, there is no way of knowing which one of these approximations is actually the true activation set.

As explained in the main text (seeÂ SectionÂ 3.2), to avoid this problem, we further constrainÂ EquationÂ 20 to the Î»ğœ†\lambda corresponding to activation sets of size at most Nmaxsubscriptğ‘maxN_{\textrm{max}}, where Nmaxsubscriptğ‘maxN_{\textrm{max}} is a hyper-parameter selected by the attacker in order to recover meaningful activation sets, and where Nmaxâ‰ªdmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘maxğ‘‘N_{\textrm{max}}\ll d in order to avoid the problem of having infinitely many solutions. This can be formalized as the following problem

Â FindÂ â€‹Î»âˆˆâ„Nâ„›â€‹Â such thatÂ â€‹â€–Î»â€–0â‰¤Nmaxâ€‹Â andÂ â€‹XÂ¯âŠ¤â€‹Î»=WÂ¯th,Â FindÂ ğœ†superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘â„›Â such thatÂ subscriptnormğœ†0subscriptğ‘maxÂ andÂ superscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹topğœ†subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡\text{ Find }\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\text{ such that }\|\lambda\|_{0}\leq N_{\textrm{max}}\text{ and }\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda=\overline{W}^{h}_{t}, (21)

where â€–Î»â€–0subscriptnormğœ†0\|\lambda\|_{0} denotes the number of non zero coefficients of Î»ğœ†\lambda. The intuition behind this restriction is that (i) we wish to recover small activation sets and (ii) it is much less likely thatÂ EquationÂ 21 has a solution with a small Nmaxsubscriptğ‘maxN_{\textrm{max}}, so that if we find one, the corresponding ğ’œ~thâ€‹(Î»)subscriptsuperscript~ğ’œâ„ğ‘¡ğœ†\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda) is likely to be equal to the true activation set ğ’œthsubscriptsuperscriptğ’œâ„ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}. In practice, to solveÂ EquationÂ 21, we solve the relaxed version

Â FindÂ â€‹Î»âˆˆâ„Nâ„›â€‹Â such thatÂ â€‹Î»âˆˆargâ¡minâ€–Î»â€–0â‰¤Nmaxâ¡â€–XÂ¯âŠ¤â€‹Î»âˆ’WÂ¯thâ€–2.Â FindÂ ğœ†superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘â„›Â such thatÂ ğœ†subscriptsubscriptnormğœ†0subscriptğ‘maxsuperscriptnormsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹topğœ†subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡2\text{ Find }\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\text{ such that }\lambda\in\arg\min_{\|\lambda\|_{0}\leq N_{\textrm{max}}}\left\|\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda-\overline{W}^{h}_{t}\right\|^{2}. (22)

We then check that the recovered solution Î»ğœ†\lambda satisfies XÂ¯âŠ¤â€‹Î»=WÂ¯thsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘‹topğœ†subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘Šâ„ğ‘¡\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda=\overline{W}^{h}_{t} with sufficient precision (if it is not the case, this means thatÂ EquationÂ 21 has no solution). In the main paper, we denote with Lrecsubscriptğ¿recL_{\textrm{rec}} the set of couples (t,h)ğ‘¡â„(t,h) for whichÂ EquationÂ 21 has a solution.

This last formulation is quite standard, and can be solved using different methods, such as orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP),Â Rubinstein etÂ al. [2008], Mallat and Zhang [1993] or the LASSO methodÂ Kim etÂ al. [2007]. In practice, we solve this problem using OMP, and Nmaxsubscriptğ‘maxN_{\textrm{max}} is selected in order to lead to clusters of reasonable size. OMP is based on a greedy algorithm and builds the activation set iteratively. At each step, it adds to the activation set the sample which is most highly correlated with the residual. It is called orthogonal matching pursuit because at each iteration, the residual is recomputed using an orthogonal projection on the current state of the activation set. For more details, seeÂ Mallat and Zhang [1993] as well as the scikit-learn documentationÂ Pedregosa etÂ al. [2011].

Appendix C Relaxation of hypotheses

We note that although we assume full-participation in the rest of the article it is not strictly necessary for SRATTAÂ to work. In addition, the local and global learning rate, batch size, number of updates do not have to be fixed. The only important thing is to perform multiple gradient updates, and that the learning rate is the same for the weights and the bias at each local minibatchâ€™s gradient step. The sum across clients could be weighted (in fact this can be included in the label variable, by adding an extra label variable kğ‘˜k for the client).

Appendix E Details on numerical experiment

E.1 Details on numerical experiment

Additional details on the metrics used.

We can see the output of SRATTAÂ as a partition of the set of recovered samples P1âˆªâ€¦âˆªPp=â„›subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘â„›P_{1}\cup...\cup P_{p}=\mathcal{R}, where the sets P1,â€¦,Ppsubscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{1},...,P_{p} which are disjoint. The sets Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} are inferred by the attacker in step 3b), and represent the largest possible groups of samples which they can build. We will assess the quality of the sample recovery process using the following different metrics.

Ïrecoveredâ€‹=defâ€‹#â€‹â„›/#â€‹ğ’ŸsubscriptğœŒrecovereddef#â„›#ğ’Ÿ\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\#\mathcal{R}/\#\mathcal{D} is the ratio of recovered samples and measures the quality of the recovery process.

ÏmatchedsubscriptğœŒmatched\rho_{\mathrm{matched}} is the ratio of samples in the dataset which have been recovered and grouped with at least another sample (that is samples that belong to Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} with #â€‹Pi>1#subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–1\#P_{i}>1).

ÏcomponentsubscriptğœŒcomponent\rho_{\mathrm{component}} is the ratio between the average size of the Kğ¾K biggest elements in the partition (P1,â€¦,Pp)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘(P_{1},...,P_{p}) and the average size of a client dataset #â€‹ğ’Ÿk#subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\#\mathcal{D}_{k} (In practice, all client datasets will be of equal size). The intuition is that the Kğ¾K biggest elements of the partition would ideally each correspond to a different client dataset.

Vnormalizedâ€‹=defâ€‹Ïrecoveredâˆ—Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰normalizeddefsubscriptğœŒrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{normalized}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}*V_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the normalized Vğ‘‰V-measure of the grouped recovered samples, where Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the Vğ‘‰V-measure Rosenberg and Hirschberg [2007] of the partition (P1,â€¦,Pp)subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘(P_{1},...,P_{p}) of â„›â„›\mathcal{R} with respect to the true partition of â„›â„›\mathcal{R} into Kğ¾K sets across the Kğ¾K-clients. Exactly in the same way that the Fâ€‹1ğ¹1F1 score mixes precision and recall, here, the Vğ‘‰V-measure mixes two measures of the quality of the partition P1,â€¦,Ppsubscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘P_{1},...,P_{p}: homogeneity hâˆˆ[0,1]â„01h\in[0,1] and completeness câˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01c\in[0,1]. Homogeneity measures the diversity of each class: h=1â„1h=1 if each Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} contains elements coming from only one client (this will be the case if we have no false positive). Completeness measures how each true client is distributed amongst different groups Pisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–P_{i} ; c=1ğ‘1c=1 if for all kğ‘˜k, all elements belonging to client kğ‘˜k are assigned to the same element of the partition Piksubscriptğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜P_{i_{k}}. Vrecoveredsubscriptğ‘‰recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the harmonic mean of these two quantities, so that Vrecovered=0subscriptğ‘‰recovered0V_{\mathrm{recovered}}=0 if either c,h=0ğ‘â„0c,h=0 and Vrecovered=1subscriptğ‘‰recovered1V_{\mathrm{recovered}}=1 if both c,h=1ğ‘â„1c,h=1. This measure is particularly adapted to our setting as we do not have a natural metric to compare different clusterings with a different number of clusters. We multiply by ÏrecoveredsubscriptğœŒrecovered\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}} so that the attacker clusters all data points and to the right client if and only if Vnormalized=1subscriptğ‘‰normalized1V_{\mathrm{normalized}}=1. ÏrecoveredsubscriptğœŒrecovered\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}} can be seen as the recall but taken over all samples not only recovered samples.

E.2 Datasets used

E.2.1 CIFAR10

CIFAR10Â Krizhevsky etÂ al. [2009] is one of the most well-known image classification datasets. There are 60,0006000060,000 object-centric images of relatively low resolution 32x32x3 that are labeled with 10 different mutually exclusive classes (horse, frog, truck, airplane, automobile, bird, cat, deer, dog, ship).

E.2.2 FashionMNIST

FashionMNISTÂ Xiao etÂ al. [2017] was released as a more challenging alternative to MNISTÂ LeCun etÂ al. [1998] with grayscale images 28x28 of fashion items split across 10 classes (T-shirt/top, Trouser, Pullover, Dress, Coat, Sandal, Shirt, Sneaker, Bag, Ankle boot). There are 70,0007000070,000 images in total.

E.2.3 DNA

Primate Splice-Junction Gene Sequences (or DNA dataset) dataset is a part of the OpenML suiteÂ Vanschoren etÂ al. [2014]. It consists of 3,18631863,186 samples which are splice junctions. Each sample is a vector of 180180180 indicator binary variables and the ML task is a 3-way classification task (ei, ie, neither). More details can be found inÂ Vanschoren etÂ al. [2014].

For all the datasets above, we use MLP networks directly on raw pixels that are just rescaled to be between 0 and 1 (with 255 distinct values).

E.2.4 TCGA-BRCA

The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA)Â Weinstein etÂ al. [2013], Tomczak etÂ al. [2015] is an open initiative to gather and make available oncology patientsâ€™ data for multiple modalities such as tabular, radiology, histology and genomics and different cancers. The TCGA is organized by study where each study focuses on a single cancer. BRCA is the BReast CAncer study. The samples in TCGA were collected across multiple institutions that are tagged by barcodes and identifiable, this is also the case for BRCA. FLambyÂ OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. [2022] uses such naturally split data inside TCGA-BRCA to provide a realistic distributed dataset where the ML task is survival predictionÂ Jenkins [2005]. For a more complete treatment of the ML task defined by this dataset see Appendix F inÂ OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. [2022]. We use this tabular dataset with 108810881088 patients and retrieve for each patient a feature obtained from its histology slides (see Primer on histology below if needed). We detail below in Histology Preprocessing the exact process used to extract such features and join both datasets.

TCGA license

The data terms can be found https://gdc.cancer.gov/access-data/data-access-processes-and-tools. In particular, as per the GDC data access policy, users should not attempt to identify individual human research participants from whom the data were obtained.

Primer on histology

Histology slidesÂ Ghaznavi etÂ al. [2013] are large-size images obtained by digitizing stained slices of biopsies of the patientâ€™s tumor sites. Such images, called Whole Slide Images (WSI), generally comprises millions of pixels representing the slice at different resolution and comprise a large uninformative background. This background has to be removed to maximize the Peak-Signal-to-Noise-Ratio of the information inside the WSI. As this data usually does not fit in GPU RAM, its dimensions are reduced using tiling and feature extractionÂ Courtiol etÂ al. [2018].

Histology Preprocessing

Like inÂ Andreux etÂ al. [2020], we use natural splits and retrieve the original histology sides corresponding to each patient using the patient ID. As some patients have multiple histology slides we keep only the first one after alphabetical sorting. We drop all patients for which histology slides could not be found (383838 in total making a final total of 105010501050 patients). We then tile the matter on each slide at x20 magnification using a U-netÂ Ronneberger etÂ al. [2015] trained on an in-house dataset and compute ResNet-50 featuresÂ He etÂ al. [2016] pretrained on IMAGENETÂ Deng etÂ al. [2009] for each extracted tile. Therefore each patient is associated with a row of clinical data and a variable number of ResNet-50 features proportional to the amount of matter found on the corresponding slide. We then train a linear autoencoder with bottleneck size 256256256 on the ResNet-50 features from all slides using an L2 cost as is common practiceÂ Schmauch etÂ al. [2020]. Once this autoencoder is trained, we encode all features in each slide. Finally, we average all autoencoded features on each slide to get a fixed-sized feature, following MeanPool architecturesÂ Saillard etÂ al. [2021]. Therefore for each patient we build a feature vector of size 39+256=2953925629539+256=295 with 393939 clinical features and 256256256 "histology" features.

Clinical Data Preprocessing We use FLambyOgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. [2022]â€™s preprocessed version of TCGA-BRCA where original features are filtered and binarized except for the age feature (of integer type), which is left unaltered. This allows us to easily define the corresponding data prior to filter out candidates. SeeÂ OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al. [2022]â€™s Appendix F1 andÂ Andreux etÂ al. [2020] for more details about the exact preprocessing steps.

Survival Loss function

One of the foundation models in survival analysis is the linear Cox proportional hazardÂ Cox [1972]. This model assumes:

hâ€‹(t,x)=h0â€‹(t)â€‹expâ¡(Î²Tâ€‹x)â„ğ‘¡ğ‘¥subscriptâ„0ğ‘¡superscriptğ›½ğ‘‡ğ‘¥h(t,x)=h_{0}(t)\exp(\beta^{T}x) (23)

where h0subscriptâ„0h_{0} is the baseline hazard function (common to all patients and dependent on time only) and Î²ğ›½\beta is the vector of parameters of our linear model. Î²ğ›½\beta is estimated by minimization of the negative Cox partial log-likelihood, which compares relative risk ratios:

Lâ€‹(Î²)=âˆ’âˆ‘i:Î´i=1[Î²Tâ€‹xiâˆ’logâ¡(âˆ‘j:tj>tiexpâ¡(Î²Tâ€‹xj))]ğ¿ğ›½subscript:ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–1delimited-[]superscriptğ›½ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript:ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğ›½ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—L(\beta)=-\sum_{i:\delta_{i}=1}\Big{[}\beta^{T}x_{i}-\log\big{(}\sum_{j:t_{j}>t_{i}}\exp(\beta^{T}x_{j})\big{)}\Big{]} (24)

where iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j index patients and Î´i=1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–1\delta_{i}=1 indicates an event. This loss is extended in our case to handling mÎ¸â€‹(xi)=ReLUâ€‹(Wâ€‹xi+b)subscriptğ‘šğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ReLUğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘m_{\theta}(x_{i})=\mathrm{ReLU}(Wx_{i}+b) instead of raw xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} where we backpropagate through Wğ‘ŠW and bğ‘b as well. This is a natural extension explored inÂ Andreux etÂ al. [2020]:

Lâ€‹(Î²)=âˆ’âˆ‘i:Î´i=1[Î²Tâ€‹mÎ¸â€‹(xi)âˆ’logâ¡(âˆ‘j:tj>tiexpâ¡(Î²Tâ€‹mÎ¸â€‹(xj)))]ğ¿ğ›½subscript:ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–1delimited-[]superscriptğ›½ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘šğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript:ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğ›½ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘šğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—L(\beta)=-\sum_{i:\delta_{i}=1}\Big{[}\beta^{T}m_{\theta}(x_{i})-\log\big{(}\sum_{j:t_{j}>t_{i}}\exp(\beta^{T}m_{\theta}(x_{j}))\big{)}\Big{]} (25)

We minimize the negative Cox partial log-likelihood by mini-batch gradient descent w.r.t. Î²ğ›½\beta. We note that, as this loss is non-separable, its gradient on mini-batches might be degenerate if the sampled batch contains only non-admissible pairs that cannot be ranked togetherÂ Jenkins [2005].

All experiments in the article on the presented datasets are repeated 101010 times in order to produce confidence intervals.

E.3 Dirichlet split of the dataset across the clients.

InÂ SectionÂ 4.2 and FigureÂ 2, we use the same method asÂ Hsu etÂ al. [2019] to split the FashionMNIST dataset into different clients, while parameterizing the heterogeneity of the data distribution by a parameter 0<Î±<âˆ0ğ›¼0<\alpha<\infty. A small value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha corresponds to a heterogeneous data distribution, while a high value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha corresponds to a homogeneous data distribution.

More precisely, for a given value of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and a given client kğ‘˜k, we draw a random vector qâ†’â†’ğ‘\vec{q} following a Dirichlet distribution of parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha of size L=10ğ¿10L=10, where Lğ¿L is the number of labels present in FashionMNIST. Such a vector satisfies â€–qâ†’â€–1=1subscriptnormâ†’ğ‘11\|\vec{q}\|_{1}=1 and qlâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘ğ‘™0q_{l}\geq 0 for l=1,â€¦,Lğ‘™1â€¦ğ¿l=1,\dots,L. The density distribution of qâ†’â†’ğ‘\vec{q} is proportional to âˆlqlÎ±subscriptproductğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ›¼\prod_{l}q_{l}^{\alpha}. For the client kğ‘˜k, we then generate a dataset of size #â€‹ğ’Ÿk#subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\#\mathcal{D}_{k}, such that the number of samples with label lğ‘™l is roughly âŒŠqlâ€‹#â€‹ğ’ŸkâŒ‹subscriptğ‘ğ‘™#subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\lfloor q_{l}\#\mathcal{D}_{k}\rfloor.

When Î±â†’âˆâ†’ğ›¼\alpha\to\infty, we have qlâ†’1/Lâ†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘™1ğ¿q_{l}\to 1/L for all lğ‘™l, therefore each client kğ‘˜k as #â€‹ğ’Ÿk/L#subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ¿\#\mathcal{D}_{k}/L samples of each label. When Î±â†’0â†’ğ›¼0\alpha\to 0, we have qâ†’â†’(0.,â€¦,0,1,0,â€¦)\vec{q}\to(0.,\dots,0,1,0,\dots), where the only non-zero component of qâ†’â†’ğ‘\vec{q} is randomly one of the Lğ¿L dimensions. In that case, each client has samples coming from only one label.

We provide in FigureÂ 3 an extension of FigureÂ 2 where we added the performance of two extra clustering algorithms: the BIRCH Zhang etÂ al. [1996] and the Affinity propagation Frey and Dueck [2007]. We could not empirically make the attack works with other standard clustering algorithms.

F.3 Another possible defense: the Î²ğ›½\beta-defense

We introduce in this section another defense, named "Î²ğ›½\beta-defense". Increasing the value of qğ‘q is an efficient way to avoid sample recovery. However, it might censor more neurons than needed. In plain english, if the linear weight of a sample contributes to the update more than a fraction Î²ğ›½\beta, we censor the neuron. We name this other defense Î²ğ›½\beta-defense, different to the qğ‘q-defense in the way it selects the neurons to censor. The results exhibited inÂ FiguresÂ 6, 7 andÂ 3 highlights that we are able while censoring less neurons using the Î²ğ›½\beta-defense than when using the qğ‘q-defense with q=4ğ‘4q=4, we successfully defend ourselves against the attack. Note that in these results the qğ‘q-defense is never used, as the Î²ğ›½\beta-defense comes as a replacement of the qğ‘q-defense.

F.4 Remark on preserving symmetry with nupdates=1subscriptğ‘›updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}=1.

The second part of the attack is relevant only if nupdates>1subscriptğ‘›updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}>1, which is the setting this paper focus on. It could be seen as a possible way of defending against SRATTA. However enforcing nupdates=1subscriptğ‘›updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}=1 by either (i) considering one batch in each round or (ii) accumulating gradient at the initial point Î¸tâˆ’1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta_{t-1}, boils down to distributed SGD. This algorithm is not suitable in all FL settings as it comes with high communication costsÂ McMahan etÂ al. [2017], and is more sensitive to gradient attacks, as studied by other workÂ Geiping etÂ al. [2020], Huang etÂ al. [2021], Hatamizadeh etÂ al. , Xu etÂ al. [2022]. As a result we do not explore this further.
